Agreed, sof, that creating a tax haven for Russian mob money turned out to be a very bad idea.

But once again Germany has shown a remarkable tin ear by creating a run on the bank. If they want to find the rescue money from people who abuse the system, then why didn't they levy something like 30% on accounts over 250,000 euros, unless the owners can demonstrate Cypriot nationality?

The truly stupid, ham-handed thing here is to tax the retirement savings of ordinary people in order to make up for the abuses of Russian oligarchs.

These Europeans need to learn from us how you do this :-)

My Credit Union savings account makes 0.3% interest, because the Fed's Quantitative Easing program but inflation is running 2.7% (officially) and increasing - jumping to an 8.4% annual rate in February, the last month data are available - because the Fed's policy of increasing inflation by increasing the money supply.

Over the last 3 years, the US government has taxed, via inflation and real negative interest rates, my Federal Credit Union savings account 8.5%

More elegant, but the end result is as precisely in Cyprus: It is the savers that pony up for the failure of the Banks. Always, always..

The ECB is just more blunt about it.

This is ridiculous... the average depositor is supposed to be able to evaluate whether a bank might have issues with solvency at some point down the road?  Putting money in a bank account is not supposed to be like investing in the stock market.  The banking system only works if people have 100% confidence and that means deposit insurance and regulations that work.

One wonders how to determine a "regular depositor" when the account holders are masked and nearly one-quarter of the deposits are held by Russians ..  much of the deposit money is gone, and it's difficult to imagine a reason why other Euro-centric populations should be required to reimburse a profligate government and the banks it encouraged to behave as they did.

Please see George Lackoff for why arguing logically with ideologues is completely useless.  One of the biggest challenges Liberals have is thinking that logical arguments change opinions.  Success is to be found in changing the narrative and telling stories from the liberal frame in ways that conservatives can also buy into.  Obama has been attempting to do this so I am not as eager to fault him as you.  I think it is easy to expect too much from the holder of the presidency.  There are three branches of government.

The problem is clearly with Obama's leadership, rather lack there of. Leadership is not compromising with ideologues, but rather providing a vision of how to move forward. Basically he has to explain to the public how misguided and obstructionist the Republicans are being and trash their public perception. You do this with constant logical rational arguments and show the fallacy of arguments of the other side. You do this several times a day by multiple people. Eventually the other side looks foolish and has to give in.

This is the leadership Obama lacks. Never had it, never will. The Republicans know this and project a better story, ie. Obama got his tax increase, now we need spending cuts. That is why they do so well at obstructing a rudderless President.

Where to begin? First: "Surviving the American Revolution that emancipated the scourge of slavery.: Sorry, wrong war. That was the Civil War.
But more to the point: "There is sympathy for those that are immersed in their peculiar lifestyles... "
I work nine-hour days, commute home to my dog; I am on the board of my Co-op; I enjoy cooking, reading and my firends. That's a lifestyle, peculiar or not. My homosexuality is no more a lifestyle than one's heterosexuality is. And I don't for one second ask for anyone's sympathy.

"To fall in line with our politicians of today"??

You do realize that politicians of any day are generally far behind the curve of public opinion? Politicians do not profess their support for anything, even if they personally believe in it, until they know public opinion is a wind beneath their wings.

Many Liberals and Democrats are unimpressed with Secretary Clinton's profession of support because she waited until polls of public opinion were at 58% in favor. An impressive politician would have "come out" at, say 40%, or less.

Concerning this country being founded on "strong religious principles", be careful to note that a clear and distinct separation between church and state was written into constitution, not to mention a clear effort to point out that "all men are created equal" and that we respect all faiths, or lack there of.

It continues to be the religious that claim this country was founded on some sort of religious principles. Some would say it is they that are our very own taliban today.

"Gay rights are human rights"... catchy slogan by Ms. Clinton.

Simply put, easy to agree with....until one gives it some serious thought. Coming from Ms. Clinton does not make it right. What are "human rights"? Surely they would vary depending in what country or civilization one lives in.

Can we now go back to the beginning of our country, with all the faults we had back then. Surviving the American Revolution that emancipated the scourge of slavery. The never ending discourse of religion and state. The give and take...the right and wrong...no one can discount the very fact that this country was founded on religious principles: Strong family ties.

To ignore the fact that the world is changing, and as President Obama has repeatedly said that we as nation must change...brings us back to our forefathers. There was no Hollywood back then. An insidious industry that has shaped today's issues, could well have been an inspiration, as it has many times in the past...yet today it is the gay community that has been propelled from it.

Our politicians of today are a sad commentary to the history of the past;, they are misreading the polls of today relating to same-sex marriage.

There is sympathy for those that are immersed in their peculiar lifestyles. it is no indication that Americans favor same-sex marriage.

To fall in line with our politicians of today, is to step over the brink of a demented nation, searching for truth, with no one to lead them, including Ms. Clinton.

Huckleberry Finn imply that Singapore has something similar to slavery. nothing can be further from the truth. no one forced those migrant workers to come to Singapore. they came seeking a better life and higher pay than what they would have gotten had they stayed in their own countries.

and, while the working conditions of these migrant workers may seem harsher than what most Singaporeans and "talented" expats have to endure, these conditions are totally unlike what the slaves in America had to suffer (employers who abuse foreign workers in Singapore are severely punished). furthermore, unlike the slaves of America, who were brought very much against their will and often with death as their only escape from slavery, the migrant workers in Singapore are very much free agents, coming on their own free will and going if they so choose.

and yes, these migrant workers are paid lesser than Singaporeans (and other "talented" expats) but one can't deny that the migrant workers who come to Singapore enjoy a far better deal than if they were to have stayed in their own countries. very often the foreign maids in Singapore, after working in Singapore for a number of years go back to their home country to live rather luxurious (by their own countries' standards) lives. and migrant workers from Malaysia may seem to be lowly paid in Singapore, but back in Malaysia, they have bigger houses and flashier cars than their friends who stayed to work in Malaysia. how is that slavery?

I've been hoping something like this would happen for a very long time. I was not a fan of the additions of schools like West Virginia, Rutgers, and Louisville. It diluted the character of the Big East.  I understand the landscape of college sports has changed.  I guess I still think that conferences should be made up of colleges that have the same educational philosophies, and thus similar student bodies. That way competition, at least during the season would be somewhat level.  The Ivy is the only pure league like this.  Big Midwest public schools are grouped together, same for the other regions.  Small Catholic schools forming a conference would be like this.  Then, the NCAA tournament would be a test to see how one type of school matched up vs. another.  I know this type of idealism doesn't really work in the 21st century, but what if it did?

Sen. Levin, one of the few adults on the Democratic side of the U.S. Senate, blocked filibuster reform for the simple reason that pundits and touts have almost universally predicted the taking of the Senate by Republicans for multiple elections now -- which they've failed to primarily owing to not-ready-for-prime-time candidates. But that can't (and won't) go on forever, particularly with efforts by people such as Karl Rove to find and support more electable Republicans.

Independent studies now have the taking of the Senate majority by Republicans at even higher probability in 2014 than the already-high probability of retaining the House Republican majority.

In these circumstances, retention of the filibuster is a highly intelligent hedge by Democrats against becoming completely inconsequential in the next Congress.

Then, Republicans have supported the confirmation of the vast majority of Mr. Obama's nominations to the federal bench, often unanimously, including two U.S. Supreme Court associate justices that the right wasn't particularly enthusiastic about. The problem with existing vacancies is that Mr. Obama hasn't teed-up nominees, not that Republicans have blocked them.

And the (very) few court nominees that Republicans have blocked with filibusters were on deeply-held ideological grounds, as deeply-held as the president's in nominating those individuals; and Senate Republicans have as much right to hold such convictions as the president has to hold his.

Unfortunately, Senator Levin may be best remembered for being one of a small minority of Democratic senators (mostly, "old bulls" like Mr. Levin) who blocked filibuster reform, insuring that the 113th Congress will be just as dysfunctional as the 112th.

He played a key role in insuring continued obstruction of president Obama's appointments to the federal bench, cabinet posts, federal agencies and quite possibly, the demise of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. That's a crucial part of his legacy, too. I won't be sorry to see him go.

Sir, this is at best a red herring argument. The point being is the situation is not perfect, and keeping it in a state of imperfection for the benefit of those who can exploit for their own ends at the expense of others is simply wrong and immoral. The poor in Singapore are kept out of sight and out of mind with little or no help whatsoever, and the mere act of placing one of these "subsidised" HDB flats near other HDB flats roused out cries of indignation over devaluations of their "property". The poor in Singapore are worse off compared to the living conditions they are living, what with their salaries not risen significantly vs the rise in costs of living. Their children do not do well in school and some even skip school to work. Yes I know you are going to claim otherwise in your ignorance, but facts remain facts. Perhaps a visit to one of the poorer neighbourhood schools or a visit to some of the older housing estates might be in order to see how the poor really live?

I am inclined to agree with Andrew's comments. What Singapore does well at is keeping its destitute out of sight. Many will faithfully recite the many dole-out schemes the government has to help the destitute. But the more important question is - how did these people get there in the first place?

One key issue that has been missing from this entire debate is related to social equality, but far more important because it is an agent to change existing social inequality - SOCIAL MOBILITY.

I would like to think, from my own experience, that social mobility is still alive and kicking in the US. The Singapore government itself has conceded that social mobility here has been decreasing over the past decades.

to Singaporean who said that "Singapore has one of the highest income inequalities in Asia, and perhaps the world". While that may be true, but that fails to recognise that our lowest paid here are not living on the street; they are living with roofs over their heads (with very few exceptions). However it is done, you can't deny that you don't see many people who have to live on the streets of Singapore because of financial (in)ability. compare this with major cities in US and UK where you do see significant numbers of people having to live and beg on the streets. Singapore's taxi drivers (perhaps a universal "low-skill" job) are able to take their families on overseas holidays and afford laptops for their children.

We have it quite good, even for the poor. I haven't read about people starving to death here or robbing each other for food money (for drug money or to settle gambling debts, yes, but to pay for food, probably doesn't exist in Singapore). I don't think this can be said of many other countries. So what's more important, a low GINI coefficient where everyone is poor, or ensuring that the poorest are not destitute?

What I do agree with Singaporean is that there is a need to lift the wages of those at the bottom of the economic spectrum,but not so much by limiting the inflow of migrant workers, but by making those at the bottom more economically productive.
